Configuration of Automated Replenishment To be competitive, a company must strike a balance with its inventory levels: The company should not overstock inventory, because this ties up working capital, yet it should avoid stockouts, which result in lost customers and diminished customer loyalty. With Acumatica ERP, you can configure automatic replenishment for stock items at a single warehouse, or at multiple warehouses (if the Multiple Warehouses feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form). If your warehouses may be used only for sales, you can configure the system so that the warehouses from which sales are performed will be replenished from the warehouses where purchases are performed (from distribution centers). Before you start to configure automated replenishment in your system, thoroughly consider the warehouse functions in your system, including which warehouses will perform consolidated purchasing, which will serve as replenishment sources for other warehouses, which will be replenished by transfers, and which will be replenished by direct purchasing. For more information about replenishment, see Automated Replenishment. Configuration Steps To reduce time that would be spent typing replenishment settings for each item in each warehouse, you can configure default replenishment settings at multiple levels. In general, you perform the following steps to configure automated replenishment: You create the appropriate replenishment classes, which group warehouses by the replenishment sources used in your company. For details, see To Create a Replenishment Class. You create replenishment seasonality entities. For details, see To Create a Replenishment Seasonality. You assign each warehouse to a replenishment class. For details, see To Assign a Replenishment Class to a Warehouse. For each item class, you specify replenishment settings for all replenishment classes, including the applicable seasonality settings. For details, see To Set Up Replenishment for an Item Class. For each stock item, you review the replenishment settings that are the default values from the item class, and make any needed adjustments. For details, see To Set Up Replenishment for a Stock Item. For each stock item at each specific warehouse, you review the replenishment settings that are the default values from the item. Adjust these settings for each warehouse if needed. For details, see To Specify Warehouse-Specific Replenishment Settings for a Stock Item. The sections below provide information that will help you execute these steps. Replenishment Classes Replenishment classes categorize warehouses by their replenishment source —that is, how stock is replenished at the warehouse. You assign a replenishment class to every warehouse. You create replenishment classes by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN208800|IN208800]) Replenishment Classes (IN208800) form; for each class, you specify its name, description, and replenishment source. As the replenishment source, you can select one of the following options: None : No replenishment is required for a warehouse. This option could be used, for example, for a warehouse that is closing its operations. Purchase : The items for stock replenishment in the warehouse will be purchased from vendors when it is determined by the replenishment settings and in the quantities calculated based on the replenishment settings. Transfer : For stock replenishment in a warehouse, the items will be transferred from a source warehouse; transfer orders will be generated automatically. This option is available only if the Multiple Warehouses feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. Purchase to Order : In warehouses with this replenishment source option selected, no actual replenishment is performed; the items are purchased only when customer orders have been received and strictly in the quantities requested by the orders. When you add an item from this warehouse to a sales order, the system automatically selects the Mark for PO check box so that a purchase order for this item can be created. Drop-Shipment : In warehouses with this replenishment source option selected, no actual replenishment is performed; the items are purchased only when customer orders have been received and strictly in the quantities requested by the orders. When you add an item from this warehouse to a sales order, the system automatically selects the Mark for PO check box so that a purchase order for the item can be created; the purchased item is sent directly to the customer. For automated replenishment, only replenishment classes with Purchase or Transfer as replenishment sources can be used. Setting Up Default Values To make it easier to provide replenishment settings for each item that are specific to each warehouse where the item is stocked, you can set up default values at multiple levels: Item class: By using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form, on the Replenishment Settings tab, you specify the replenishment settings to be used as the default settings for items of the class. If you know that items of the class are stocked at multiple warehouses with different replenishment sources, configure how the items are typically replenished for each replenishment class. For each item class, you specify the following information: The method of demand calculation, which you select in the Demand Calculation box. If you select Hard Demand Only , the demand will be calculated as Qty. SO Allocated + Qty. SO Shipped + Qty. SO Back-Ordered . If you select Item Class Settings , the demand will be calculated in accordance with the availability settings specified for this item class on the General Settings tab of the same form. The seasonality. The replenishment method: None , Min/Max , or Fixed Reorder Qty . For the second or third option, specify the parameter (the reorder point quantity) required to determine the need for replenishment. The demand forecast model and parameters for the model (the period type, number of periods to analyze, and service level). The launch and termination dates of the period when the settings are effective for the class. The default replenishment settings for a newly created item class are those from the parent item class. If the created item class has no parent, the default replenishment settings are those of the class that is specified in the Default Stock Item Class box (if you are creating a stock item class) or the Default Non-Stock Item Class box (if you are creating a non-stock item class) box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form. Stock item: On the Replenishment Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, you can view the replenishment settings of a particular item, which by default are provided by the item class. For the item, you can review the replenishment settings for different replenishment classes that might be used if the item is stocked at multiple warehouses, and override the settings if needed. Subitem: If subitems are used in your system, on the Replenishment Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form, you should specify parameters for each subitem. If only the default subitem is used with for the item, you specify the parameters for this default subitem; if different subitems of the item require different replenishment quantities, you specify the parameters that are different. Subitems inherit all other replenishment settings from the item. Replenishment Settings for an Item at a Particular Warehouse The many replenishment settings for all items at all warehouses are filled in with default values. On the Replenishment Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form, you can review the replenishment parameters to be used for the particular item at the selected warehouse. These settings come from the item settings but can be overridden for this item stocked in a particular warehouse. For the item, you cannot use a replenishment source other than the one specified for the warehouse where the item is stocked. Also, you can override the values of the replenishment parameters used for particular subitems, if in this warehouse they differ from the default values specified for subitems on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form. Configuration of Consolidated Purchasing for Replenishment With Acumatica ERP, you can configure replenishment for a number of warehouses that is performed by centralized purchasing to one large warehouse, a distribution center, and by transfers to smaller warehouses—this ensures that purchasing is performed more efficiently. You have to make sure that for items in the warehouse (which is a distribution center), Purchase is selected as the replenishment source on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form with no replenishment warehouse selected. For items in the smaller warehouses (which should be replenished by purchasing to a distribution center), you specify Purchase as the replenishment source and select the distribution center as the replenishment warehouse on the Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details form. First, you must prepare replenishment requests for small warehouses by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN508000|IN508000]) Prepare Replenishment (IN508000) form and generate transfer orders requesting replenishment by using the form. After that, you will be able to generate purchase orders on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO505000|PO505000]) Create Purchase Orders (PO505000) form—the system will create a single purchase order for all the requested quantities of each item. Additionally, you can run the process of preparing replenishment in the distribution center before you generate consolidated purchase orders for smaller warehouses, to add to consolidated purchase orders the quantities requested for replenishment in the distribution center. Upon receipt of the items (once receipts are released), you will be able to replenish the stock in the distribution center and to fulfill transfer orders by the appropriate number of shipments to all the demand warehouses. If the item is replenished by using the Purchase to Order source, for each warehouse where the item is stocked, you can specify the same replenishment warehouse. Then, when you generate purchase orders on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO505000|PO505000]) Create Purchase Orders form, the system will create a single purchase order for all the requested quantities of the item, no matter what are the demand warehouses. After you create a receipt for the merchandise from a vendor for this purchase order and release it, the system automatically generates transfer orders to split the received quantity between demand warehouses according to the quantities on the original sales orders. Configuration of Replenishment by Transfers If the Multiple Warehouses feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can configure replenishment for a number of warehouses that is performed by transfers from one large warehouse, a distribution center, for which centralized purchasing is performed, and perform purchasing efficiently. For items in the smaller warehouses that should be replenished by transfers from the distribution center, specify Transfer as the replenishment source, while for the same items stocked in the distribution center, select Purchase as the replenishment source. First, you must prepare replenishment for small warehouses by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN508000|IN508000]) Prepare Replenishment (IN508000) form and generate transfer orders requesting replenishment—this will create demand for replenishment in the distribution center. After that, you will be able to generate replenishment requests for the distribution center. The next stage in the replenishment process is generating purchase orders on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO505000|PO505000]) Create Purchase Orders (PO505000) form—the system will create a single purchase order for all the requested quantities of each item. Upon receipt of the items (once receipts are released), you will be able to fulfill transfer orders by appropriate number of shipments. Replenishment Methods and Their Parameters With Acumatica ERP, you can assign different replenishment methods to different items of inventory stocked at a single warehouse or different warehouses and specify warehouse-specific parameters for these methods. Different items may require different parameters because of different customer demand for them and different numbers of days required to receive the requested quantities from the vendors. You can use either of the following replenishment methods: Min./Max. or Fixed Order Qty . For each stock item, the system uses the specified method to calculate the quantities required to replenish the stock of this item, based on the replenishment parameters that you specify on the Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. The available replenishment methods and their parameters are discussed in the sections below. Min./Max. Method You use the Min./Max. method to maintain the stock level of an inventory item at a particular warehouse between the specified minimum and maximum quantities. To use this method for an item, you should specify the following parameters: Maximum Quantity : This is the maximum stock quantity allowed for the item at the warehouse. Safety Stock : This is the additional stock of the item maintained to avoid stockouts. A safety stock is required if there are fluctuations in demand and supply. Because safety stock is not used in calculation for this method, add the quantity of the safety stock to both maximum quantity and reorder point quantity . Reorder Point : The system uses the reorder point quantity in the Min./Max. replenishment method rather than a minimum quantity. The quantity to be used as the minimum quantity is specified in the Reorder Point column on Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. Generally, the reorder point quantity would be estimated as the quantity that may be required during the lead time (the time when the product is being shipped from the vendor location to your company). If you need to maintain safety stock, include the safety stock quantity in the reorder point quantity. Once the system detects that current stock level (the available quantity) of the particular item has reached or fallen below the reorder point, it calculates the quantity required to replenish the item stock up to the maximum quantity by adding the quantity on demand to the difference between quantities of the maximum, on hand, and on supply. You control the way the system calculates the quantities on demand for classes of stock items by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN204500) form as follows: Hard Demand Only : For all stock items of the class, the demand is calculated as (Qty.SO Allocated) + (Qty SO Back-Ordered) + (Qty SO Shipped) Item Class Settings : For all stock items of the class, the demand is calculated in accordance with the availability options selected for the item class on the General Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes form. Fixed Order Quantity Method You use the Fixed Order Quantity method when you want to replenish the item stock with a fixed quantity each time it falls below the reorder point. This method uses the following parameters: Fixed Quantity : We recommend that you use as the fixed quantity the economical order quantity (EOQ) determined by warehouse specialists for a particular item by estimating the cost of ordering the item from a particular vendor. For each vendor from which the stock item can be purchased, the EOQ is specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO201000|PO201000]) Vendor Inventory (PO201000) form. You can view EOQs specified for all vendors of the item on the Vendor Details tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form. Safety Stock : This is the additional stock of the item maintained to avoid stockouts. The safety stock is required if there are fluctuations in demand and supply. Reorder Point : For this method, too, the reorder point is specified as the safety stock plus the quantity that may be required during the lead time. With the Fixed Order Quantity method, the system generates request for the economical order quantity (EOQ) for the item once it determines that the available quantity reaches or is lower than the reorder point. Parameter Estimation For automated replenishment, you can manually enter estimates of replenishment parameters—such as safety stock, maximum quantity, and reorder point—that were made externally by logistics specialists for each item. Alternatively, you can configure the system to automatically calculate the replenishment parameters. In Acumatica ERP, you can use demand forecast models to calculate replenishment parameters by using sales statistics. For overview of the functionality, see Replenishment Parameters Based on Demand Forecast . With this flexibility, you can lower carrying costs, avoid stockouts, minimize excess or obsolete inventory, improve cash flow, and increase customer loyalty levels. Other Item-Specific Parameters The parameters described below are also used in automated replenishment for the inventory item at the specific warehouse: Launch and Termination Dates : These dates define the range during which the replenishment settings specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form will affect the item if it is stocked at this warehouse. By default, the dates come from the item settings (which are specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form but can be overridden for the item at the specific warehouse). Vendor Details : To replenish the stock of the inventory item at the warehouse, you should specify the vendor from which inventory will be purchased. The system uses the default vendor of the inventory item (as specified on the Vendor Details tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form) unless you have selected another vendor for the item at the warehouse. The following item-specific parameters are associated with the selected preferred vendor: The lead time required to ship the item from the vendor location to the warehouse The lot size, if specified, which rounds up the order quantity for the mix/max method to multiples of lot size The minimum order frequency (the minimum number of days between two successive orders) The minimum and maximum order quantity The EOQ Subitem Details If your company uses subitems in your implementation of Acumatica ERP, you can also specify the replenishment parameters for each subitem of the item stored at the warehouse. On the Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, you can generate the list of all subitems of the inventory item. By default, all subitems have the same parameter values, copied from the values for the default subitem. On the Subitem Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form, you can create a list of subitems stocked at the warehouse and specify replenishment parameters for each subitem. Separate replenishment quantities will be calculated for each subitem, based on subitem-specific parameters and the current quantity on hand (of the item with this subitem) at the warehouse. Replenishment Parameters Based on Demand Forecast Businesses strive to have enough stock for potential sales. Replenishing the stock in time and in the proper quantities helps businesses to retain customers while reducing storage costs. For an overview of the automated replenishment functionality implemented in Acumatica ERP, see Automated Replenishment. To predict the demand—that is, the stock level you may need in the future for each item—you can use demand forecast methods. The current version of Acumatica ERP uses the moving average method, one of the simplest methods. In Acumatica ERP, you can use the predicted average daily demand, calculated with the help of demand forecasting models, to periodically update the values of replenishment parameters (such as maximum quantity, reorder point, and safety stock) in order to more precisely calculate the quantities required for replenishment. Using the Moving Average Method With the moving average method, you calculate the demand for a specific future period based on historical sales data for multiple consecutive periods in the immediate past. This method works well for items with specific trends in sales or with stable sales not subjected to random significant fluctuations. The moving average model of forecasting demand is configured at the item level—on the Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form—and can be defined at the item class level on the same tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form. (A new stock item inherits the settings of the selected item class, but you can override the class settings.) When you select Moving Average as the Demand Forecast Model of replenishment on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items or ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes form, you also specify the following settings: Forecast Period : The type of time period to be used for the selection of historical data and for demand calculation. The following options are available: Quarter , Month , Week , and Day . Period to Analyze : The number of periods of historical data of the specified type to be used for calculation. Service Level : The service level, whose default value is 84. In the calculation of replenishment parameters, the system uses the inverse of the standard normal cumulative distribution of the service level as follows: NORMSINV(Service Level) . With this formula, for a service level of 84%, the result is 1; for a service level of 50%, the result is 0. Seasonality : The seasonality, which can be used to normalize the replenishment quantity to accommodate high and low sales seasons. Launch Date : The date starting the time period when the specified replenishment settings will be in effect. This forecast model uses the data available for the specified number of past periods to forecast demand for the period immediately following the last period whose data is used in forecasting. If you select a month as the forecast period and want to perform a forecast on the 15th day of the current month, 15 days' worth of data will not be used for forecasting; only data from full periods is used. The system calculates the daily demand for the nearest future period based on daily sales in all days of the specified number of prior periods. As the actual data for the last forecast period becomes available, you can forecast the demand for the next period by using the data of the previous periods shifted by one period. This method smooths out the data; the more periods you use to calculate the average demand, the greater the smoothing effect. The average lead time is calculated for each stock item‒preferred vendor pair based on all purchase orders in the system history. The average lead time is computed as average difference (on all orders) between the date when an order is created (the Requested on date) and the date of the receipt created for the goods listed on the order. Using Seasonality Parameters for Forecasting The sales of some products follow certain cycles or patterns. For example, the peak of ski sales is in the winter. These patterns in sales can be described as seasonality . A set of seasonality settings is a list of low and high seasons with appropriate factors (coefficients) that show how sales decline or increase in each of these specific seasons, as compared to average sales volumes calculated over all time. The seasons for particular products or groups of products with similar sales behavior and corresponding factors can be determined by analyzing sales data spanning several financial years. You define seasonality settings by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206600|IN206600]) Replenishment Seasonality (IN206600) form. The seasons for one seasonality should not intersect. For date ranges not included in any season, the factor is 1.0 by default. A low season for groups of products may span multiple financial periods or be contained in a single financial period. The seasonality settings are used as follows: The system normalizes the historical data available for the specified seasons. The sales volumes for each day of a season are deleted by the appropriate factor to calculate the sales quantities as though it were a normal season. The system calculates the average daily sales quantity based on the historical data of the specified number of periods. For seasons within the specified periods, the system uses the normalized data. The standard deviation for the daily demand is calculated for actual sales data, not for normalized data. The average daily sales quantity is adjusted for seasons if seasons are expected within the forecast period. The average daily sales is multiplied by the average seasonality factor (calculated over all days in the forecast period—normal days and days of seasons). Calculating Replenishment Parameters By using the calculated average daily demand (daily sales), average lead time, and their standard deviation values, the system computes the following parameters used in automated replenishment: Reorder Point and Safety Stock . The reorder point is calculated by using the following formula: (Reorder Point) = (Average Daily Demand) * (Average Lead Time) + (Safety Stock) The safety stock is calculated as follows to address possible fluctuations in demand (daily sales): (Safety Stock) = NORMSINV(Service Level) * SQRT((Average Lead Time * STDEV(Daily Demand))^2 + (Average Daily Demand * STDEV(Lead Time))^2) Parameters used in these formulas are the following: Average Daily Demand is the average daily demand (average daily sales), calculated as the item quantity on all sales orders, credit memos, transfers out, and kit assembly documents in all the time periods used to analyze the data divided by the number of days. STDEV(Daily Demand) is the standard deviation of daily demand (daily sales quantity) from the average quantity. Average Lead Time is the average lead time (in days) calculated by using the following formula: (Average Lead Time) = SUM((Requested on Date) – (Purchase Receipt Date)) / (Amount of Purchase Orders) STDEV(Lead Time) is the standard deviation of lead time (in days) from the average value. NORMSINV(Service Level) is the service factor, which is calculated based on the service level specified as a percentage. The service level is used to optimize the safety stock level. Generally, it is set on the item-class level, but it can be specified for each item in each warehouse if needed. The service level represents the probability of stockout not being reached. The NORMSINV(Service Level) function provides the factor that adjusts the safety stock required for the specified service level. With the service level selected at 50%, the safety stock is zero (that is, not required). The factor reaches 1.0 with the service level approximately 84%, which is the default value for the service level on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form. To maintain a higher service level, you will need a safety stock that exceeds the calculated quantity. Calculation of the daily demand forecast depends on whether the launch date is specified in the Launch Date box on the Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form as follows: If the launch date is empty, the calculation period starts from the date of the first sales (if this date belongs to the current calculation period). If the launch date is specified, the calculation period starts from the launch date and is rounded to the selected forecast period (such as a week or month). For correct calculation of the demand forecast, we recommend that you specify the launch date and select the beginning date of the forecast period close to the launch date. For an example of the calculation of the replenishment parameters for the moving average method, see An Example of Replenishment Parameter Calculation. The Maximum Stock is set equal to Reorder Point ; if needed, you can manually increase the value of Maximum Stock . Setting Up Parameter Calculation You specify the forecast method and its parameters for each item class by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form, and then the settings are used as default values for items of the class. You can select values that differ from the default ones for particular items of the class by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. Moreover, if the Multiple Warehouses feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can adjust the replenishment settings for each warehouse in which the items are stocked. Splitting Parameters by Subitems If subitems are used in your system, you can use demand forecasting to calculate replenishment parameters for specific subitems of the items if having enough stock for these subitems is important to your business. For such items, on the Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, specify the initial replenishment parameters for each of the subitems used. After that, the system will calculate parameters for each listed subitem by using the forecasted daily demand (daily sales) for the specific subitem. All subitems of the item should be listed in the Subitem Replenishment Parameters table. If specific subitems do not require replenishment, specify zero values as their parameters. Updating Replenishment Parameters by Using Forecast-based Values You use the following Acumatica ERP forms to update replenishment parameters and then prepare the replenishment: ([~/?ScreenId=IN508500|IN508500]) Calculate Replenishment Parameters (IN508500): You use this form to compute the average daily sales and average lead time, and then to calculate the following parameters used in automated replenishment: Max. Qty. , Reorder Point , and Safety Stock . ([~/?ScreenId=IN509500|IN509500]) Apply Replenishment Parameters (IN509500): On this form, you review the parameter values suggested by the forecast and replace the old values of replenishment parameters with the suggested (calculated) ones. You can manually adjust the suggested parameters if needed. ([~/?ScreenId=IN508000|IN508000]) Prepare Replenishment (IN508000): You use this form to find the items that need replenishment and to calculate replenishment quantities for these items. ([~/?ScreenId=PO505000|PO505000]) Create Purchase Orders (IN505000): You can use this form to generate purchase orders for items requiring replenishment. ([~/?ScreenId=IN509500|IN509500]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN208800|IN208800]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN206600|IN206600]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN508000|IN508000])

An Example of Replenishment Parameter Calculation Suppose that on March 1, ABC company first purchased a new gadget for bikers (the New Gadget stock item) and sold it to a local sporting goods store, Best Sports. Best Sports decided to order 200 units during April and May. The ABC company's purchasing manager, who is responsible for sales of the New Gadget item, decided to use the following default replenishment parameters during these three months of sales: Safety Stock : 20 Reorder Point : 50 Max Quantity: 200 These parameters were specified for the New Gadget stock item on the Replenishment Info tab on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. Before extending the sales to other customers, the purchasing manager has decided to collect the relevant sales data during the first three months and then calculate the replenishment parameters based on this data using the following settings: Forecast Type : Month Periods to Analyze : 3 Launch Date : March 1 The purchasing manager tracks the New Gadget related events and collects the data as follows. Timeline of purchasing, receiving, and replenishing New Gadget Business Date Business Event March March 1 ABC company prepares replenishment for New Gadget. March 1 Purchase order for 200 units of New Gadget is created, approved and sent to the New Gadget vendor. March 15 The Best Sports store places a sales order for 200 units. March 21 ABC company receives 200 units of New Gadget. Purchase receipt for 200 units is released. March 22 Shipment to the Best Sports store is confirmed. March 31 ABC company collects the data: Total Sales: 200 units; Daily Demand: 200/31=6.45; Lead Time: 20 April April 1 ABC company prepares replenishment for New Gadget. April 1 Purchase order for 200 units of New Gadget is created, approved and sent to the New Gadget vendor. April 15 The Best Sports store places a sales order for 200 units. April 18 ABC company receives 200 units of New Gadget. Purchase receipt for 200 units is released. April 22 Shipment to the Best Sports store is confirmed. April 30 ABC company collects the data: Total Sales: 200 units; Daily Demand: 200/30=6.67; Lead Time: 17 May May 1 ABC company prepares replenishment for New Gadget. May 1 Purchase order for 200 units of New Gadget is created, approved and sent to the New Gadget vendor. May 15 ABC company receives 200 units of New Gadget. Purchase receipt for 200 units is released. May 15 The Best Sports store places a sales order for 200 units. May 22 Shipment to the Best Sports store is confirmed. May 31 ABC company collects the data: Total Sales: 200 units; Daily Demand: 200/31=6.45; Lead Time: 14 June June 1 The ABC company uses the collected data to calculate the replenishment parameters. On June 1, the purchasing manager initiates the calculation of replenishment parameters by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN508500|IN508500]) Calculate Replenishment Parameters (IN508500) form. The service level for the New Gadget stock item is selected as 90%. The system calculated the replenishment parameters as follows. Parameter Suggested Values Explanation Average Daily Demand 6.52 (200 + 200 + 200) / (31 + 30 + 31) STDEVP(Daily Demand) 0.10 STDEVP(200/31, 200/30, 200/31) Average Lead Time 17 (20 + 17 + 14 ) / 3 STDEVP(Lead Time) 2.45 STDEVP(20, 17, 14) Service Level 90% Normsinv(Service Level) 1.28 Safety Stock 20.6 1.28 * SQRT((17 * 0.1) ^ 2 + (6.52 * 2.45) ^ 2) Reorder Point 131.49 (17 * 6.52 + 20.6) Max. Quantity 131.49 As this simple example shows, the reorder point should be increased to 131 units mostly due to a rather large average lead time.

To Create a Replenishment Class If you want to configure automated replenishment in your organization, you have to create each replenishment class that will provide the replenishment source by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN208800|IN208800]) Replenishment Classes (IN208800) form, as described in this topic. Before You Proceed Open the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. Make sure that the Inventory Replenishment feature is enabled To Create a Replenishment Class Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN208800|IN208800]) Replenishment Classes (IN208800) form. On the form toolbar, click Add Row . In the Class ID column, type the unique identifier to be used for the replenishment class. In the Description column, type a brief description of the class. To Create a Replenishment Seasonality If your organization sells items with a seasonal demand and you want to replenish these items automatically, you have to create seasonality entities in the system by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206600|IN206600]) Replenishment Seasonality (IN206600) form, as described in this topic. Before You Proceed Make sure that the Inventory Replenishment feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. Make sure that a calendar you will use in the seasonality settings has been created on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS209000|CS209000]) Work Calendar (CS209000) form. To Create a Replenishment Seasonality Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206600|IN206600]) Replenishment Seasonality (IN206600) form. On the form toolbar, click Add New Record . In the Seasonality ID box, type the unique identifier to be used for the seasonality. In the Description box, type a brief description of the seasonality. In the Calendar box, select the calendar that will be used for determining low seasons and for gathering sales statistics. In the table, do the following for each date range that you want to include in the current seasonality: On the table toolbar, click Add Record . In the Season Start Date column, type or select the date when the season starts. In the Season End Date column, type or select the date when the season ends. In the Factor column, type the coefficient that the system will use to reduce or increase item replenishment quantity between the start and end dates. On the form toolbar, click Save .
